reviewText: I first saw this as a kid some 20 years ago on a late show on TV. Beign that it's the first major sound film, it's interesting. Apparently, they got the hang of it as they were going along in th emaking of this film. Everyoone's discussed the plot already, so I have nothing new to add to that, aside from it being an interesting look on Jewish-American assimilation issues in the 20s. As an African-American, I wasn't overtly offended by Jolson's use of Blackface in this film, partially because as a history teacher I could put it in context along with the fact that (in my opinion),nothing about Jolson's perfomance here degrades the African-American in the way that many films of the era (or even recent times) have done. He puts on the makeup, sings two songs, and he's himself for the rest of the film (compare this to the crude minstrel show Jolson was to do in "Wonder Bar" some years later). But either way, see it for a history lesson.

reviewText: There's been a lot of things said about this movie for going on 80 years now, some negative things and some positive things, and some things which seem to be said by people who haven't even seen the movie, judging by how inaccurate these comments are.  I was expecting this movie to be pretty dated, and came away from it feeling that, while certain aspects were a bit dated, overall it wasn't as much of a museum piece as some people feel it is.  It might be hard to relate to a young man who gets cut off from his family as though he were dead just because he wanted to sing jazz songs instead of training to become a cantor like his father and other male relatives before him, and why that was considered such a shocking big deal, but the basic premise is still there--it might not mean being kicked out of your house and being declared dead in your parents' hearts, but everyone can relate to following a dream or a life path different from the one expected of you or dictated by tradition, even if the consequences are no longer that severe and it no longer seems a dichotomy to reconcile both tradition and modernity without watering down either.  Some of the Jewish stereotypes were a bit bothersome, such as the portrayal of Yudelson and the frequent references to Judaism as a "race" and how the people were praying to "their" God, but at least it wasn't as bad as the racism in, say, 'Birth of a Nation.'A lot of people who claim this was the first all-talking, all-singing motion picture clearly haven't even seen it, nor are they familiar with cinematic history.  There were experimental films featuring music and dialogue as early as the 1890s, although certainly they didn't catch on, and the technology was cumbersome, impracticable, and rather expensive.  The sound in this film was a result of the success of the 1926 John Barrymore film 'Don Juan,' which featured some synchronised sound and music (and Jolson himself had appeared in a one-reeler from 1926, 'A Plantation Act,' which was truly all-talking, all-singing).  Still, this is by and large a silent film; only maybe a quarter of it features actual sound, and nearly all of that sound is singing, although there are a few dialogues.  It almost gives the feeling of actually being back there in 1927 and watching this film where every so often you're caught off-guard by the sound of, well, sound, not being used to anything like that, even if most of it is rather crudely and primitively synchronised and tacked-on (though the sound does look and sound more natural as the movie wears on).  The first true all-talking picture was still a little bit off; this wasn't it, despite the hype.  It's also completely untrue that this automatically ended silent cinema; such a big sea change did and could not happen overnight, instead taking till 1929 for nearly all films to have sound.  A lot of people seem to have the impression that this film came out and then automatically every single film that came out afterwards was a talking picture.Like many others who haven't seen the film, before seeing it I assumed a lot of it would feature Al Jolson in blackface, a very dated entertainment.  When I finally saw it, I was proven wrong; despite what most posters of the movie and even most covers of the video depict, he's only in blackface for a couple of songs near the end, and sings them very matter-of-factly, the same way he matter-of-factly applies the makeup and puts on his wig.  He just sings these songs in blackface and really is himself for every other part of the movie; he doesn't ham it up by "acting" Black as well, the way he is said to do in some of his later pictures.  The concept behind blackface entertainment is patently racist and offensive, but it wasn't always presented in a racist way.While not really Oscar material, it is a pretty good story, and quite touching in spots.  Young Jakie has dreams of being a jazz singer instead of a cantor, and runs away from home at quite a young age to pursue his dreams in peace, although he still secretly keeps in touch with his mother (as one intertitle says, "God made her a woman and love made her a mother"), being a bit of a mama's-boy.  He becomes an up-and-coming hit, but a kink is throw into his plans and rise to the top when he comes home to New York to sing in a show taking place there and his father (who is celebrating a birthday) is furious to find him at home.  Jakie, now called Jack, is rather hurt, saying he came home with nothing but love in his heart and is now being turned away, not even being given a chance.  The big show he is set to sing in happens to take place on the eve of Yom Kippur, and he must decide if he sings to advance his career or comes home to sing Kol Nidre in place of his father, who has taken ill and is unable to sing the beautiful age-old melody.  The ending of the film is also incredibly sweet and heart-warming.  Al Jolson might not have been the world's best actor, and his songs might be viewed more like curiosities today, but he had the *personality* to project this story and make it come to life.

reviewText: Other than a handful of experimental short films and a feature that added only music and sound effects to the motion picture experience, Al Jolson's "The Jazz Singer" was the first film to feature sound.  To understand why this was such a big deal involves more than an obvious "duh" on the part of any interested viewer; it requires a viewing of this remarkable piece of history.As a movie, "The Jazz Singer" is memorable but not an especially great film.  Jolson, more or less the Elvis of his day, was a huge draw in the first place, as now people in any nickelodeon could walk in and not only hear Jolson but see him singing at the same time.  That was big.  With the passing of 80 years his talent is underwhelming, and he was no better as an actor than Elvis himself, but none of this is the point; what is really striking about "The Jazz Singer" is that it is mostly silent.By watching the film we therefore can reproduce the experience of one of those early fans who flocked to see this revolutionary motion picture experience so long ago.  It opens with several scenes of typical silent movie action with musical accompaniment, then a scene with a singing child portraying Jolson's character in his early years.  The sound doesn't exactly match the visual, kind of like a Godzilla movie.  Later there's a scene featuring his father, the rabbi, singing in the synagogue; the singing more closely matches the visual, but is not in sync.Then, later, Jolson as an adult makes his debut in a nightclub, and with his voice perfectly synchronized with the visuals the full effect of motion picture with sound comes into place.  He sings a sentimental ditty about kids called "Dirty Hands, Dirty Face," and we can see how early film fans must have been awestruck at the quantum leap between silent and sound.  But "Wait, you ain't heard nothin' yet," Jolson says to the applause of the nightclub patrons, and another dimension is added; hearing chatter and seemingly off-the-cuff patter takes us from the level of performance to something much more intimate, and from that moment forward only Chaplin could manage to get away with making a silent film, and he only a few."The Jazz Singer" is an interesting phenomenon for the above reasons.  It switches back and forth between silent and sound for its duration, and the effect of added synchronous sound is always quite striking.  Anyone who loves movies and hasn't seen this film really owes it to themselves to do so.
summary: Why was sound such a big deal?

reviewText: On the verge of bankruptcy, in 1926 Warner Brothers decided invest in the Vitaphone sound system. Warner figured, at that point, what did they have to lose? Thus they took a chance.  Don Juan was their first Vitaphone film, but it only contained music and sound effects. In 1927 Warner adapted the Samson Raphaelson Broadway hit The Jazz Singer into a movie and, this time, they incorporated vocal musical numbers in what was still a silent film for all but twenty minutes. Al Jolson starred as Jakie Rabinowitz, the son of a Jewish cantor. Tradition dictated that he follow in his father's footsteps. However, Jakie preferred to sing jazz. Friction between he and his father over this issue caused Jakie to leave home, change his name to Jack, and become a cabaret performer. When Jack returns years later to visit his parents, he is warmly greeted by his mother (Eugenie Besserer), but is still rejected by his father. Just as Jack is about to break into the big-time career-wise, he is told that his father is dying. Jack misses opening night so he can sing the Kol Nidre at the temple in his father's place. His dying father, in his final moments, hears Jack performing the sacred songs, forgives his son, and dies in peace. Contrary to popular belief, audiences had heard music on film before, and they had heard dialogue on film before. What they had not heard or seen before were either of these things being particularly entertaining. When Jolson sings "Blue Skies" to his mother while adlibbing humorous comments, it all came across as so completely natural that people suddenly realized that sound on film could be entertaining and not just some novelty act.  Despite its many shortcomings, including the predictable storyline, The Jazz Singer was a box-office success.Today, you can best appreciate this movie by putting it in historical context. The best comparison I can make is that it was - although on a much larger scale - the "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" of its day. That 1988 film was also a hit only because of technological achievements that looked wondrous at the time, and today if you see it you will also probably wonder "What was the big deal?". As an aside, the actual first all-talking picture was 1928's "The Lights of New York". If you ever see that film, "The Jazz Singer" looks polished in comparison. In "The Lights of New York", the camera's immobile, the acting's on par with lumber, the script is third-rate, and you have to love that dialogue - "Take.. him... for... A... ride".  I'd love to see a DVD come out with both of these films with some commentary by someone like Robert Osborne on the technology versus art driving the films of that transitional era.
summary: An interesting  window into the past with a largely forgettable script

reviewText: When Warner Brothers released THE JAZZ SINGER in late 1927, talking pictures, which had failed commercially, finally became official. The story, about a Jewish cantor's son who defies family tradition by pursuing a theatrical career was cliched even then, yet this phenomenal film singlehandedly shook the foundation of the entire motion picture industry. Now, eighty-six years later, it's easy to see why - not only for its towering historic importance, but also for its enduring entertainment value due in great measure to its charismatic star, Al Jolson.Directed with breezy assurance by Alan Crosland, THE JAZZ SINGER was partially based on Jolson's own life, and seldom, perhaps never again, has a performer projected a more enthusiastic portrayal of himself in a feature film. Jolson's signature style with which he belts out the songs and his genuine rapport with an audience is still pretty powerful. Even though styles and attitudes have changed since the '20's, there's something about Jolson that remains modern.Back in 2007, Warner Home Video released a fabulous three-disc DVD edition of THE JAZZ SINGER that served the film well with painstakingly restored picture and audio reproduced from the original Vitaphone lacquer discs. In addition, the set boasted scores of archival extras, mainly the 3 1/2 hours worth of rare and wonderful Vitaphone shorts. As nice as that was, there were still some minor issues with the main feature involving a bit of picture wear and an out-of-sync section. Warner's new Blu-ray Book Edition of THE JAZZ SINGER not only corrects those glitches, but transcends the DVD in terms of overall image and audio quality. Truly, this has to be one of the most dazzling, meticulously restored home video releases ever of a film of this vintage. The 1080p resolution reproduces to a tee what cinematographer Hal Mohr captured with his camera, and this is without the intrusion of DNR. The audio is likewise crystal clear and hiss-free, impressing us with just how good the original Vitaphone recording process was.While the feature is in HD most of the extra material, which has been transferred over from the previous release, is still on two standard DVDs. The only things missing here are the trailers to a few of Al Jolson's other films and the photo cards. The gorgeous digi-book combines the pamphlets and contains a bit more information than the DVD set.Bottom line: Is it worth upgrading your great looking/sounding DVD? Yes, because the Blu-ray of this landmark film blows it away.NOTE: If you can't get enough of those historic Vitaphone shorts, I highly recommend VITAPHONE VARIETIES VOLS. 1 and 2, and VITAPHONE CAVALCADE OF MUSICAL COMEDY, from the Warner Bros. Archive Collection. All together, they total 148 entertaining gems that serve as a veritable window to the past.

reviewText: In 1927 Warner Brothers Studios and Al Jolson ushered in the era of sound films with The Jazz Singer, sparking a revolution in the movies unlike anything before or since. Five panicked studios reacted by banding together in a futile gesture of resistance to sound films, with only Warner Brothers and Fox pursuing expansion of the "talkies". Within a year the doubters abandoned their pact, and scrambled to catch up as the public demanded talking pictures. Looking at The Jazz Singer today, it is hard to grasp the enormous impact it had. It is the melodramatic story of the Jewish Cantor's son who wants to defy the tradition of five generations and become a theatrical singer. It is a mix of the old and the new, with exaggerated facial and hand gestures, lots of synchronized music and singing, and less than 2 minutes of synchronized dialogue. It was this last that excited audiences in 1927. Compare the histrionics of the silent acting accompanied by printed intertitles, with the subtleties of Jolson's live sound conversation with his mother about moving out of the ghetto and up to the Bronx. It is the difference between night and day, and audiences wanted more daylight.This three-disc Warner Brothers release, available in both DVD and Blu-ray, does a fine job of telling the story of the rise of sound films, with a beautifully restored Jazz Singer as its centerpiece. Disc one is devoted to The Jazz Singer, with extras pertaining specifically to the film; disc two has a feature-length documentary about the development of motion picture sound as well as other shorts and excerpts illustrating the first years of sound; and disc three is a 3 hour collection of short sound films produced by Warner Brothers' subsidiary Vitaphone. The second and third discs are artistically rendered to look like miniature versions of the original Vitaphone discs.Although sound films are generally regarded as an overnight success dating from 1927, in fact sound pictures had been in development since 1894, when Thomas Edison made his first sound film. By the 1920s several individuals or companies were releasing short sound movies, including Lee Deforest, Vitaphone, and Western Electric. Wealthy young inventor Theodore Case was making home movies of his dogs and his kids with better sound than the commercial firms could produce. The Jazz Singer employed Vitaphone's recording system which used 16-inch records and a turntable spinning at 33 1/3 rpm, mechanically linked to the projector motor to ensure perfect synchronization of the sound with the pictures. The discs were only good for 20 performances, after which they were discarded and replaced with a new record.Four films in consecutive years trace the ultimate triumph of sound, and all are discussed briefly in the extras that accompany The Jazz Singer. In 1926 John Barrymore starred in "Don Juan", a silent picture with added synchronized music and sound effects. It was a big hit, so in 1927 Warner Brothers upped the stakes with The Jazz Singer, with synchronized music, songs and just a bit of dialogue. Encouraged by the smash success of Jazz Singer, Warner followed in 1928 with the first all-talking feature length film, "The Lights of New York". It was a mediocre film, but a great success due to its novelty. In 1929 Warner produced another Jolson film, the all-talking "Singing Fool", which became the biggest box office film up to that time, a record it held for ten years until it was eclipsed by Gone With The Wind in 1939.The Jazz Singer is a valuable addition to any film collection, and Warner makes it especially worthwhile by providing hours of extras. This compilation offers a fascinating account of the advent of the sound era, with its triumphs and failures, winners and losers. The Deluxe Edition DVD and the Blu-ray release are delights for fans of Hollywood history.
summary: The Jazz Singer and the Sound Revolution

reviewText: When you acquire this DVD set, you are not just purchasing a copy of the first partial talking feature film, you are purchasing a brief history of the development of sound movies, and of one of the great entertainers of the early 20th century.Contained in this set are three discs:Disc 1 contains "The Jazz Singer" and the picture is in beautiful shape considering its age. (You will note that excerpts shown in some of the later documentaries don't look near as good.) "The Jazz Singer", when viewed purely as entertainment, is an average film at best. But one must view it from the perspective of its place in history, and from that point, it is really a thing of beauty.Filling out the first disc is "A Plantation Act", an Al Jolson sound short produced by Warner Brothers prior to "The Jazz Singer"; the cartoon, "I Love to Singa"; and the shorts "An Intimate Dinner in Celebration of Warner Bros.' Silver Jubilee", "Hollywood Handicap", and "A Day at Santa Anita". The last two shorts both have cameos by Jolson. "A Day at Santa Anita" stars the delightful Sybil Jason (every bit as talented as Shirley Temple), but sadly, the Technicolor alignment is in dire need of repair, so it is at times a chore to watch (doubly disappointing to me, as a Jason admirer).Disc 2 contains a brand new documentary, "The Dawn of Sound: How Movies Learned to Talk"; surviving sound excerpts from the (sadly) missing movie, "Gold Diggers of Broadway" (yes, "Tip Toe Through the Tulips" is included, contrary to another reviewer here on Amazon); and several studio shorts relating to the sound era. These sound shorts are rather repetitive, as they cover much the same territory as the feature documentary on this disc.As for that feature documentary, I came away with a much better perspective of the timeline of the early sound era. Naturally, it leans heavy on the contributions of Warner Brothers, but the other studios (Fox, MGM, and Universal) also get both a mention and several clips.Disc 3, to me, was the gem of the set, and would have been worth the price if it were the only one included. It contains 24 early sound shorts (over four hours). Some are simply filmed sessions with orchestras or other musical talents, but there are some hilarious comedy routines among them, as well. One has a difficult time keeping a straight face through the acts by Shaw & Lee, Ethel Sinclair and Marge LaMarr, and, of course, Burns & Allen. Also note that there is a delightful short of Baby Rose Marie (yes, THAT Rose Marie) singing several tunes.Also included with the set are two sleeves (both, unfortunately, poorly glued together) containing photos and reproductions. I found these an okay touch, but not really worth a lot in the long run.All in all, given the massive amount of content, the quality of the content, and the condition of the films, I cannot give this set anything less than a full five stars. The only strikes against the set would be the condition of "A Day at Santa Anita" (please, Warner, do some restoration of this film), and the poor construction of some of the packaging. Yes, "The Jazz Singer" is not an all-time classic from a content perspective. But when viewed in the proper context, this is a set that every classic movie lover must have.

reviewText: Almost immediately after Warner Bros' huge financial gamble premiered in Oct 1927, other studios' concerned bigwigs frantically ordered their studios to immediately equip themselves to do sound movies. New careers were made -- and shattered -- overnight. If you haven't seen The Jazz Singer, considered the first "talking movie" (even though there actually were some earlier sporadic experiments) this is a video worth not only seeing but OWNING for several reasons: a)You see Al Jolson at his height. He was one of the first half of the 20th century's biggest stars and some of his stage charisma comes through in this movie's songs. Most of the flick is actually silent except for the songs. Originally he was only supposed to sing, but he ad libbed a few lines and the response was absolutely electric when audiences heard and saw him say these few words on the screen. b)The story's value: a Jewish religious leader's son, torn between tradition (using his voice for religion and following in his dad's footsteps) or to please the masses (as a jazz singer in vaudeville). Follow family tradition or national culture? c)The historical show biz value: the Warner brothers put everything they on the line in  doing this flick and if it had failed sound movies would have been set back about 10 years (or more)  -- and maybe Bugs Bunny wouldn't have been invented. d)Technical show biz value: The Warners used Vitaphone, which was basically sound on disks synchronized to the film's action. You also get a nice zippy period musical score throughout the movie. f)American history historical value: Note long shots of the Jewish ghetto. They were actual shots of a New York street taken through a window -- NOT extras on a movie set. And the theater in which Jolson sings was the Wintergarden, a theater in which he often performed. g)Cultural historical value: even though Jolson's belt-em-out vocal style (effective in theaters without mikes) is part of the reason you don't hear about him anymore,  a MAJOR part of his vanishing public historical profile is because he did some of his stage act in "blackface" and minstrel shows were viewed a bit differently in those days. You will SELDOM EVER see this film aired on television due to the fact that blackface is so obviously politically incorrect (understatement!). Does this hold up? YES, it is corny but it is also deeply touching and Jolson's stage pizazz reaches across nearly a century on most  numbers (one or two now are almost "camp" but weren't back then). Advice: it won't be available on video forever as the 21st century advances. And you might not find it at your local rental store. Get it now. It's the movie that forever changed Hollywood -- and it's still entertaining.

reviewText: "The Jazz Singer" is a hard film to rate; after all, as the first "talking" motion picture it is of great historical importance, but on the other hand, it is pure melodrama.  It is maddening when Al Jolson has an extended sequence singing for and talking to his mother (Eugenie Besserer), only to see the film return to title cards when he has a dramatic confrontation with his father (Warren Olander), the fourth generation cantor who can not believe his son is wasting his talent as a "jazz singer."  I must admit, I always thought the story here was an extremely interesting choice for the first talking picture.  Adapted by Alfred A. Cohn (with titles by Jack Jarmuth) from Samson Raphaelson's play "Day of Atonement," this film must have told many Americans most of what they ever knew about the Jewish religion and sacred music; Cantor Joseff Rosenblatt appears as himself in a Concert Recital while Joseph Diskay provides the singing voice for Cantor Rabinowitz.  Ultimately what makes me gives this all five stars is quite simply the "sound."  I mean much more than Jolson's fantastic singing and the songs by Irving Berlin ("Blue Skies"), James V. Monaco  ("Dirty Hands, Dirty Faces") and others.  I am thinking about the entire musical score.  Because we have the original vitaphone recordings with Jolson's songs and the bits of dialogue, we also have the complete original score.  Of course for most silent films the musical accompaniment was a organ score, often an impromptu effort by the organist.  Sometimes, as with "The Jazz Singer," there is an orchestral score and it is the musical soundtrack that really carries the emotional weight of this film.  I have to wonder: is this an above average example of a film score?  It certainly seems that way to me.  In most silent films, unless we are talking Chaplin, the musical score is pretty much beneath notice and often quite irritating.  Here the only unseemly moments are when a snatch of classical music we actually realize suddenly pops up.  "The Jazz Singer" may simply be the oldest great film score in existence and we can probably only make haphazard guesses at what other great scores might have been lost.  The important thing here is that when you get around to watching this film, or watching it again, pay attention to all of the music and not just the songs.  I think you will be impressed with pretty much everything you hear.

reviewText: The Jazz Singer with Al Jolson is one of those must-see movies because it so clearly shows a shift in generations. Right in this one movie you can see the legacy of silent films - the vast majority of the film has no vocals at all and uses standard cards to show dialogue. But there are brilliant moments of song - with a few bits of dialogue - where you can hear the singing of the characters. This became a momentous time in movie making. Audiences demanded more, and while some people rose to stardom as a result, others saw immediate declines as their squeaky / scratchy voices were revealed to an unforgiving public.The movie is also fascinating because it shows a real glimpse into the Jewish ghetto situation in New York City. Those are actual streets they're showing in some scenes. This is exactly what it looked like back in the 1920s. Al's character is torn between his family's singing traditions and the new, modern music. Can he reconcile the old world and the new?The movie gets kudos for featuring a strong female character in May, something that many other period films don't do. That being said, the movie sadly doesn't even have two named female characters ever talk with each other. Is that really so hard to ask? Surely there could have been a scene where she talks with the Mom about her life choice, or talks with another woman at the theater company about life on the stage. In the end May is just there to support Al - and she doesn't even flinch when he says he loves his job more than he loves her.Yes, there are scenes where Al is in black face. Quite a few scenes. I won't get into whether this is morally good or bad or indifferent - but it was a fact of the time and the movie portrays it well. He clearly knows what he's doing and has done it many times before, so this is a good documentary on how it was done and how the people of the time perceived it.Highly recommended as a fantastic look into a complex period in US history, both within the story and in the context of the movie itself changing expectations.

reviewText: The Jazz Singer will forever be a milestone in motion picture history; it is the first full length film to include audible dialogue and musical numbers. The plot moves along well, never being too slow or too fast; and the acting is so convincing that I was never once bored. The casting, choreography and cinematography all work well and the musical score for the silent portions of the film enhance it all, too.When the film starts, we meet the Rabinowitz family living on New York City's lower east side. Cantor Rabinowitz (Warner Oland) is furious with his young son Jakie (Robert "Bobby" Gordon) who is caught singing in a saloon by Moisha Yudelson (Otto Lederer) on the eve of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement. The cantor wants his thirteen year old son Jakie to sing only in the synagogue and become the synagogue's cantor when he is too old to continue. After all, the cantor reasons, five generations of Rabinowitzs have had a cantor in the family; the cantor demands that Jakie follow in his footsteps to become the next cantor.However, Jakie doesn't want to sing in the synagogue. Jakie prefers to sing ragtime songs and other popular music of the day; there's a huge conflict between father and son after Yudelson tells the cantor that Jakie is singing in a saloon. The cantor goes to the saloon, drags Jakie out and takes him back home where he beats Jakie much to the chagrin of Jakie's mother Sara (Eugenie Besserer). Jakie then runs away and vows never to return home because he just can't live his life the way his father wants him to. Jakie may be young; but already he wants to become his own man and have his own identity.As the years go by, Jakie travels far and wide in search of fame. He finally gets a big break when a star, Mary Dale (May McAvoy), recognizes Jakie's talent and recommends him highly for a Broadway show in which she's starring! This means the big time for Jakie if he can succeed on the Broadway stage--and it also means that Jakie (now going by the name of Jack Robin) will have a chance to return home with love in his heart and hopefully make peace with his father and reunites sweetly with his mother.Of course, there's more to the plot than this and I won't say much more so you can enjoy this as much as I did! True, some of the dialogue and scenes are embarrassingly dated; but overall this film retains its historical significance. And wow, how they made a great choice to have Al Jolson perform the musical numbers in this film--he was so able to belt out songs that even the relatively primitive microphones picked up every note he sang!If you get the three DVD edition of this film there is a cornucopia of extra features that will entertain you for hours! I really liked "A Plantation Act" with Al Jolson from 1926; and the photo stills on good quality paper as well as the "souvenir booklet" are impressive. I also appreciated the documentary entitled "The Dawn of Sound: How the Movies Learned to Talk;" the surviving sound excerpts from "Gold Diggers of Broadway" and the Vitaphone comedy and musical shorts.I highly recommend this film for anyone who is a fan of the main actors in it; film buffs; people studying the advent of sound in motion pictures and anyone who likes dramas with musical numbers. True, there are certain aspects of the film that reflect the prejudices of the day; but the picture remains historically significant and rather nicely presented in this format.

reviewText: I saw this movie for the first time last night and I watched it mainly because of its' historical value.  Although I don't want to overdo this, I have to say that I was impressed with the quality of the movie.  It's the story about the son of a Jewish cantor who prefers to sing jazz rather than following in his father's foot steps.  This is more than his father can accept and he does the "I have no son" routine (I must have missed it if he tore his clothing).  His mother, of course, thinks otherwise and secretly stays in touch.  We see the son, Jack Robin (changed from the original Jacob Rabinowitz), get his start in the show biz circuit as a jazz singer.  He meets a girl and begins the slow climb to success.  Obviously his path will cross again with his father's and that part is the highlight of the story.We all know that "The Jazz Singer" is historical because it was the first movie with sound.  What impressed me is how it is a sort of cross-over movie.  "The Jazz Singer" starts out as a silent movie and about two thirds of it is silent while the other third is sound.  Most of the sound is singing with some audio dialogue before and after the singing.  I thought the movie was trying to do a sort of "Wizard of Oz" concept with one world in one style (black and white/silent) and the other world in an opposite style (color/sound).  However, I finally came to the conclusion that the sound set was only present during the singing and, therefore, picked up any dialogue during those takes on those sets.  Still, the contrast between the old and the new made the historic nature of the movie all the more effective.Unfortunately the film is all too historical to the era with Al Jolson doing his main acts in black face.  Maybe you remember the "All in the Family" TV show episode when Archie was preforming at his lodge in black face.  How ridiculous that looked in a modern day setting.  By and large the Jewish scenes in the movie were respectful although I was bothered by the references of how the Jews were worshiping "Their" God.  The character of Moishe Yudleson was made up to look like an 18th Century concept of Shylock.I came to the realization that this was the first movie musical.  (Well DUH!) I didn't do any research on this but it would be a joke of classic proportions if I'm wrong about it.  I mention this only because I concluded that the desire to bring singing to the movie screen was the driving force behind this new innovation of sound.  The story would have survived in tact as a silent picture if the father had wanted his son to follow him in becoming a rabbi instead of, say, an actor.  For me, this made the innovation of sound all the more interesting.  While the movie industry continues to expand its' horizons with newer and better special effects and in its' use of computers, it's interesting to note that it has historically found new ways to expand its' artistic abilities.

reviewText: The Jazz Singer (Alan Crosland, 1927)The iconic image of The Jazz Singer today is, of course, Al Jolson in blackface singing "Mammy", and that image is often pulled out and waved around as some sort of evidence of widespread racism in early Hollywood, or something like that. I wonder how many people have actually seen the movie behind the image? Because there's a great deal more to the scene than Al Jolson pretending to be a black man. In fact, the entire movie centers around Jolson's character-- a Jew-- trying to pass for what he is not. The blackface, which he dons for a few scenes towards the end of the film, is a perfect, if perhaps heavy-handed, symbol of the struggle Jake Rabinowitz (Jolson) is going through. In the course of the movie, he has done his level best to avoid his Jewishness, turning away from religion to become a jazz singer, even changing his name to the more gentile-sounding Jack Robin; his whole life is what it is because he doesn't want to go into the family business as a cantor. His father (Warner Oland) has disowned him, assuming that singing jazz rather than hymns is profaning his gift; when the turning point of the movie comes, when Jake Rabinowitz and Jack Robin have to come face to face and find a way to work out their differences, that's when the blackface comes out. Jolson's character is, for all intents and purposes, two different people. How else to express such a thing, especially in the silent era, when expressionism was the default mode? Turn him into a flapper? (Imagine the stir that would have raised.)The Jazz Singer is a movie intimately concerned with the subject of race. If that makes it racist in your mind, so be it. You should, however, learn the difference at some point. ***
summary: I don't understand readings of The Jazz Singer as racist...

For film buffs, however, it's an essential video because of it's historical significance and no real classic movie collection is complete without it.

reviewText: The other reviewers on this page are quite eloquent concerning Al Jolson's history-making feature "The Jazz Singer," so this writer defers to them concerning the feature film's content. You should be aware, however, that this DVD is a new restoration. The sound technicians have gone back to the original, vintage-1927 Vitaphone soundtrack discs, which offer a fuller and more dynamic tone than the previous video releases (deriving from sound-on-film prints struck in the 1950s).This is one DVD package that is so full of extras that the bonus material is just as important as the feature, if not more so. The 1947 "Lux Radio Theatre" radio adaptation of "The Jazz Singer" is included; Jolson, whose career was jump-started by "The Jolson Story," re-creates his 1927 movie role here. Ludwig Donath and Tamara Shayne, who played Jolson's parents in the movie biographies, appear as  "Jakie's" parents in the radio version.Most of the bonus features are theatrical short subjects, which are fascinating. Some of them put "talking pictures" in historical context, either as a contemporary explanation of this new invention to audiences of the 1920s, or a nostalgic, backward glance at the dawn of sound.The real fun here is the wide array of "Vitaphone Varieties" reels, recently restored with superior picture and sound. Almost all of these are vaudeville acts, featuring musical and comedy performers filming their routines for posterity. George Burns and Gracie Allen (in their first movie, vintage 1929), "Baby" Rose Marie, and William Demarest (in "the Night Court") will be familiar to today's audiences but most of these troupers won't. For a sample: vivacious Blossom Seeley and laid-back Benny Fields sell a reel's worth of songs; comic bandleader Dick Rich hilariously tries to conduct his dance band; trick musician Sol Violinsky plays piano and violin simultaneously; Al Shaw and Sam Lee do a ridiculously funny patter act, in defiant deadpan; Trixie Friganza does a clever stand-up routine (they saved this one from nitrate decomposition just in time); Adele Rowland offers poise and charm in a vocal medley; and Ethel Sinclair and Marge LaMarr "At the Seashore" deliver delightfully catty remarks as they survey the other beachgoers. Many more acts are featured, including the jazz bands of Paul Tremaine, Georgie Stoll, Gus Arnheim, and the versatile Ingenues (who play different instruments, then all-identical instruments). Last but not least is a very predictable but very funny Vitaphone comedy, "The Happy Hottentots," in which song-and-dance men Joe Frisco and Bobby Callahan find themselves in vaudeville hell, repeatedly singing choruses of "Mandy Lane" for slave-driving theater manager Billy Gilbert.If you're at all interested in what big-time vaudeville was like in its heyday, or if you're a vintage-film buff who has never seen these early-talkie reels, or if you just want to relax with a good assortment of light entertainment, you'll thoroughly enjoy the exhibits on display here. These new, restored prints of the Vitaphone Varieties are a revelation, technically and artistically. Highly recommended.
summary: Five stars for the EXTRAS! If you already own the feature on VHS, you might seriously consider this new offering

reviewText: On a newsgroup I frequent, someone recently posted a paragraph from some subtext maven, deeply probing the "inner meanings" of the Jazz Singer putting on blackface. As a lit major myself, I found the maunderings of this one pretentious and asinine (perhaps I am out of touch with the higher lit criticism these days) and responded to the piece by pointing out a bit of the history of black performers with and without the use of makeup in the U.S. following the Civil War.  My curiousity piqued, I got the film in this three-disk set and watched it last night.  As most probably know, this was the first "talking" feature picture and came out in 1927; this version is remastered and sharp and clear.  Even the sound is pretty good, though I was a bit startled at how little of it there was.  Most of the story line is produced as a silent, with title cards providing the dialogue and pantomime the action--in general only the musical numbers are heard.I am sorry that I cannot now find the passage by the lit major, but _this_ lit major and sometime actor saw the makeup scene in a very different way.  I saw a consummate professional applying a perfect makeup in about 60 seconds flat.  If you have done this sort of thing yourself, you instantly recognize that this man has done it thousands of times; Jolson "made it big" in blackface on Broadway in 1910, and so had at least 15 years of practice there and as a headliner in vaudeville (6-12 shows weekly, plus matinees Saturday and Sunday):  his hands knew just where to go.  I was particularly taken by the ear treatment in which each ear was crumpled into its makeup hand and came out smoothly black in less than half a second.  He was looking at a mirror but probably didn't need it.I can recommend the film, both as a historical artifact and as a moving piece of work in its own right.  Personally, I am looking forward to the "bonus material" of early sound attempts, other vaudeville headliners and the like--3.5 hours worth.People bothered by blackface performers are likely to be the same as those striving to remove the "N word" from Huckleberry Finn: pseudo literates with little sense of history and no reading thereof.

reviewText: ...which may or may not be a good thing!NOTE: This review refers to WB's 2007 3-DVD boxed set, which is the only one to buy. Ignore any other discs or reviewer's complaints about "cheap DVD-Rs". The WB set is the real deal and is actually inexpensive, so there's no reason to buy any other disc.This 3-disc set includes a beautiful print of the 1927 Al Jolson film, which has great moments as well as cringe-inducing scenes. It'll never be considered a great film, but it sure is an important one.Disc 2 includes a documentary as well as some early sound films, including two surviving reels of the 1929 technicolor musical "Gold Diggers Of Broadway". It's a substantial chunk of the film, and very satisfying.The remainder of the disc includes various shorts (1926 - 1955) dealing with the sound film, including early demonstration films. Well worth watching.Disc 3 is chock full of Vitaphone shorts. You need to see these to appreciate how much sound screwed up the motion picture industry. Early sound films were generally awful, including "The Jazz Singer". They almost destroyed Hollywood during the 1928-1929 seasons. First, these vaudeville performances are wooden, due to the ambience of the sound stage and the lack of an audience. Second, the sound quality (as well as the 1928 playback quality) was very poor. Urban moviegoers were used to full orchestral accompaniment; now they had to put up with tinny sound from a weak speaker high up in the theatre. And rural moviegoers couldn't see many movies at all during this period - they didn't have access to theaters with sound capabilities. But at least the novelty caught on, and eventually people accepted sound films as they improved.So why am I giving this 5 stars? Because this was a HUGE period in the development of cinema, and this 3-disc set will serve you well if you're interested in learning more about it (and experiencing it for yourself). The transfers are superb. I actually like watching these films, and I hope you will, too.
summary: A treasure trove of early sound...

reviewText: "The Jazz Singer" will forever be remembered as being the first Hollywood movie to make the transition from the silent era. However, if not for its label as the first talking picture, "The Jazz Singer" would have been long forgotten and would not have earned a place in the AFI's top 100 movies list.The first 20 minutes or so of "The Jazz Singer" has 'classic status' written all over it. It is very good and if the remainder of the movie continued the same way, the film would merit at least 4 1/2 stars. However, the film soon dips down and never quite regains itself. It loses its direction, the dialogue continually becomes more amateurish and at times it's an effort to watch.The story is of Jakie Rabinowitz, a young Jewish man who wants to break away from following his family's traditions and pursue a career as an entertainer, much to the disapproval of his father. Many will find the story to be cliched and over used. However, given the films age, this aspect can be overlooked. But either way, the film ultimately doesn't stand the test of time and must be watched from a historical viewpoint. Talking pictures had just started and this was uncharted territory. Some of the actors seem uncomfortable with the transition and it shows sometimes on screen.That being said, "The Jazz Singer" is something that is only sought after by critics and movie buffs. It's worth a look but the average moviegoer will find it an ordeal to watch.

reviewText: "The Jazz Singer," available for the first time on Blu-ray, is often mistakenly referred to as the first movie with sound.  It is the first feature film with completely synchronized dialogue and musical sequences, but much of it is essentially a silent movie.  It stars the biggest pop celebrity of the era -- Al Jolson -- in a tale with considerable similarities to his own life story.  Jolson portrays a would-be entertainer whose show business aspirations conflict with the values of his cantor father (Warner Oland).  Based on a 1925 play, "The Jazz Singer" premiered in New York City in October, 1927, in the Vitaphone process, in which a 16-inch disc was synchronized with standard 35-millimeter projection equipment (the industry would eventually change to the sound-on-film process, where a magnetic soundtrack was imprinted on the film alongside the picture)."The Jazz Singer" was a huge success in the approximately 200 theaters with sound equipment, and within two years, nearly 8,000 theaters were wired for sound. The film features a number of Jolson's trademark songs:  "Toot-Toot-Tootsie Goodbye," "Dirty Hands, Dirty Face," "My Mammy," and a then-new song composed by Irving Berlin, "Blue Skies."The three-disc Blu-ray edition contains a full-length documentary feature, "The Dawn of Sound: How Movies Learned to Talk;" four hours of Vitaphone shorts featuring George Burns and Gracie Allen, Baby Rose Marie, Blossom Seeley, Elsie Janis, and several other vaudeville performers; vintage cartoons; a 1947 "Lux Radio Theater" broadcast starring Al Jolson; and an 88-page book containing behind-the-scenes collector's cards, lobby cards, souvenir program, vintage documents, and a post-premiere telegram from Al Jolson.
summary: An important movie in Film History
